channel.title: Homeland Security Research
channel.description: Updated Homeland Security Research content from the US Environmental Protection Agency

item.title: 2016 EPA International Decontamination Research and Development Conference
item.description:
Hosted by EPA's National Homeland Security Research Center (NHSRC)

November 1-3, 2016
EPA's Research Triangle Park Campus, North Carolina
Auditorium C

Join us for the 9th international conference on decontamination research and development hosted by U.S. EPA's Office of Research and Development's National Homeland Security Research Center. The conference is designed to facilitate presentation, discussion, and further collaboration on research and development focused on chemical, biological, and radiological (CBR) contamination incidents, including those from terrorism or natural disasters.

Please note: The conference abstract submission deadline of August 31, 2016 has passed. We are no longer accepting abstracts to the conference. Please contact EPA_Decon@icfi.com for further questions.

ATTENTION: The registration to the conference has now closed.  Please contact EPA_Decon@icfi.com for further questions.

  • Announcements
    • ATTENTION - REAL ID ACT
      Visitors with a driver's license from the following states — IL, MO, MN, WA — and territory — American Samoa — must ensure they have a new, enhanced license or bring one of the following: Federal ID, US or foreign passport, green card, or US military ID. This is in response to the REAL ID Act, which went into effect on July 21, 2014.  
    • Non-EPA attendees who will bring their laptop to the conference should complete this Laptop Authorization Form and bring to the EPA security desk when you check in.

    Please note: The conference abstract submission deadline of August 31, 2016 has passed. We are no longer accepting abstracts to the conference. Please contact EPA_Decon@icfi.com for further questions.

  • Agenda

    Conference Agenda (PDF)(8 pp, 264 K)

  • Registration

    The registration to the conference has now closed.  Please contact EPA_Decon@icfi.com for further questions.

  • Abstract Submission

    Thank you for your interest in the 2016 International Research and Development Decontamination Conference. The conference abstract submission deadline of August 31, 2016 has passed. We are no longer accepting abstracts to the conference. Please contact EPA_Decon@icfi.com for further questions.

  • Presentation Guidelines

    Submit your presentation by Tuesday, October 25, 2016 to EPA_Decon@icfi.com. Bring a back-up copy of your presentation on a memory stick.

    • Time limits will be strictly enforced!
      • Speaker presentations (PowerPoint or PDF format) will be 20 minutes followed by a 5 minute question and answer period.
    • We suggest limiting your presentations to no more than 15 slides; a general guideline is to have one slide per 1.5 to 2 minutes of the presentation.
      • Please avoid elaborate animation.
      • If using video clips in your presentation, please have them available as separate files.
    • Meeting room equipment will include:
      • Laptop computer with internet access and MS Office PowerPoint 2013
      • LCD projector
      • Screen
      • Podium with microphone
      • Laser pointer
    • Slides will be made publically available on a password-protected website in PDF format after the workshop and as part of the EPA conference report; prior to the workshop ICF will request permission from you to post your slides and for inclusion in the EPA conference report. Do not include confidential or company-sensitive information in your presentation.
  • Poster Guidelines

    The poster session will be held on Wednesday afternoon.

    • Posters can be displayed from 8:00 AM to 5:30 PM; attendance at the poster location is requested only during the poster session. Multiple posters to be presented by the same author will be placed adjacent to each other.
    • Each poster session author will be provided with a poster board (4' height x 6' width). The board will indicate the poster number in upper right and left corners. Authors are responsible for mounting their own material at any time prior to the poster session on Wednesday, November 2 AND for removing it by the end of the same day.
    • All illustrations, charts, etc., to be posted should be prepared in advance as materials for these purposes will not be available at the meeting site. EPA will provide a reasonable supply of push pins but we suggest authors provide their own if possible.
    • Authors may wish to bring extra copies of their data and conclusions. No duplication facilities will be available through EPA. Authors may also wish to provide sign-up sheets for attendees who may wish additional information, reprints, etc.
    • We discourage the use of laptop computers or other equipment for multimedia presentations during the poster session. If you must use a laptop or other equipment to support the poster, please contact the organizers at EPA_Decon@icfi.com prior to the conference to discuss the need.
  • Logistics/Hotel Information

    Logistics

    EPA Employees are requested to reference conference code MS262658 when preparing their travel authorization.

    Hotel

    A block of hotel rooms has been reserved at the prevailing government rate (currently $99/night) at the Comfort Suites Raleigh Durham Airport. Please make your hotel reservation by calling 1-919-314-1200 and requesting a room under the group reservation name, "EPA Decontamination Conference". Be sure to mention that this is a group reservation to ensure you receive the group discounted rate.

    Transportation

    A shuttle will provide round-trip transportation to and from the conference for attendees staying at the Comfort Suites Hotel.

    Questions?
    ICF International, a contractor to EPA, is organizing the logistics for this meeting. If you have questions about lodging, transportation, or registration, please contact:

    • Susan Blaine at 703-225-2471 or email EPA_Decon@icfi.com
  • Organizing Committee

    If you have technical questions about the content of the conference or your proposed presentation, please contact a member of the Conference Planning Committee.

    Lukas Oudejans, Chair, 919-541-2973
    Timothy Boe, Co-Chair, 919-541-2671
    Brendan Doyle
    Matthew Magnuson
    Tanya Medley
    Sanjiv Shah
    Jeff Szabo

item.title: Guide to Requirements for Research Reports Submitted to the National Homeland Security Research Center
item.description:
Guidance for contractors and EPA employees on preparing reports for the Homeland Security Research Program

  • Guide for preparing reports for the Homeland Security Research Center (PDF)(10 pp, 1 MB, March 2, 2016)
item.dc:creator: Knickel

item.title: Notice of Willingness to Participate in Funding Opportunities of Other Federal Agencies
item.description:
Researchers within the Homeland Security Research Program (HSRP) may be willing and available to participate with an eligible institution to prepare a joint assistance application in response to a Request for Application (RFA) issued by another federal agency. Depending upon the circumstances, EPA may request some of the assistance funding or may be willing to participate as an unfunded collaborator.

  • Instructions for Participating in Funding Opportunities of Other Federal Agencies (PDF)(2 pp, 191 K, 10-19-15)
    Instructions for agencies to request collaborations with HSRP researchers
item.dc:creator: Knickel

item.title: Rapid Screening and Preliminary Identification Techniques and Methods – Companion to Standardized Analytical Methods for Environmental Restoration Following Homeland Security Events (SAM), Revision 5.0
item.description:
This document is included in Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM). 

Citation:

U.S. EPA. 2010. Rapid Screening and Preliminary Identification Techniques and Methods – Companion to Standardized Analytical Methods for Environmental Restoration Following Homeland Security Events (SAM), Revision 5.0. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA/600/R-10/090.

Description:

Report

Purpose/Objective:

The Rapid Screening and Preliminary Identification Techniques and Methods document provides information regarding procedures for use when multiple laboratories are needed to perform rapid preliminary analysis of environmental samples following a homeland security event. The information is intended to support the analytical methods listed in EPA’s Standardized Analytical Methods for Environmental Restoration Following Homeland Security Events (SAM), Revision 5.0.

  • Rapid Screening and Preliminary Identification Techniques and Methods – Companion to Standardized Analytical Methods for Environmental Restoration Following Homeland Security Events (SAM), Revision 5.0 (PDF)(106 pp, 1 MB, 09/2010)
item.dc:creator: Anonymous

item.title: Rapid Radiochemical Method for Phosphorus-32 in in Water for Environmental Remediation Following Homeland Security Events
item.description:
This document is included in Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM). 

Citation:

U.S. EPA. Rapid Radiochemical Method for Phosphorus-32 in Water Following Homeland Security Events, Revision 0. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA/600/R-11/181, November 2011.

Description:

Analytical Method

Purpose/Objective:

EPA’s Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM) lists this method for analysis of phosphorus-32 in drinking water samples.

  • Rapid Radiochemical Method for Phosphorus-32 in in Water for Environmental Remediation Following Homeland Security Events (PDF)(19 pp, 340 K, 11/2011)
item.dc:creator: Anonymous

item.title: ASM Sentinel Laboratory Guidelines for Suspected Agents of Bioterrorism: Coxiella bernetii
item.description:
This document is included in Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM). 

Citation:

ASM. 2003. “Sentinel Laboratory Guidelines for Suspected Agents of Bioterrorism: Coxiella burnetii.”

Description:

Reference Document

Purpose/Objective:

EPA’s Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM) lists this reference for additional information regarding Select Agents Culture Methods.

  • ASM Sentinel Laboratory Guidelines for Suspected Agents of Bioterrorism: Coxiella bernetii (PDF)(10 pp, 351 K, 06/26/2003)
item.dc:creator: Anonymous

item.title: CDC, ASM, APHL: Basic Diagnostic Testing Protocols for Level A Laboratories for the Presumptive Identification of Bacillus anthracis
item.description:
This document is included in Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM). 

Citation:

CDC, ASM and APHL. 2002. “Basic Diagnostic Testing Protocols for Level A Laboratories for the Presumptive Identification of Bacillus anthracis.”

Description:

Analytical protocols

Purpose/Objective:

Revision 4.0 of EPA’s Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM) lists this document for culture techniques analysis of Bacillus anthracis in environmental samples.

  • CDC, ASM, APHL: Basic Diagnostic Testing Protocols for Level A Laboratories for the Presumptive Identification of Bacillus anthracis (PDF)(22 pp, 570 K, 03/18/2002)
item.dc:creator: Anonymous

item.title: SAM 2012 Appendix A: Selected Chemical Methods
item.description:
This document is included in Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM). 

Citation:

U.S. EPA. 2012. Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM) 2012. Appendix A.

Description:

SAM Appendix

Purpose/Objective:

This Appendix to EPA’s Selected Analytical Methods for Environmental Remediation and Recovery (SAM) lists chemical methods that have been selected for each SAM chemical analyte and sample type, along with assigned tiers to indicate a level of method usability.

  • SAM 2012 Appendix A: Selected Chemical Methods (PDF)(16 pp, 186 K, 07/16/2012)
item.dc:creator: Anonymous
